title: Mitsuo Ogasawara
text:
is a former <a href="Japanese%20people">Japanese</a> <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player. He played for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>.
Club career.
Ogasawara was born in <a href="Morioka">Morioka</a> on April 5, 1979. After graduating from high school, he joined <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a> club <a href="Kashima%20Antlers">Kashima Antlers</a> in 1998. He debuted in April 1998 and played many matches as offensive midfielder from 1999. In 2000, he became a regular midfielder and Antlers won the champions all three major title in Japan; <a href="2000%20J.League%20Division%201">J1 League</a>, <a href="2000%20J.League%20Cup">J.League Cup</a> and <a href="2000%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a> first time in <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a> history. At <a href="2000%20Emperor%27s%20Cup%20Final">Emperor's Cup Final</a>, he scored 2 goals and contributed to won the champions. The club also won the champions <a href="2001%20J.League%20Division%201">2001 J1 League</a> for 2 years in a row. In <a href="2002%20J.League%20Cup%20Final">Final</a> at <a href="2002%20J.League%20Cup">2002 J.League Cup</a>, he scored a winning goal and Antlers won the champions. He was also selected MVP award. He was also selected Best Eleven award in J1 League for 5 years in a row (<a href="2001%20J.League%20Division%201">2001</a>-<a href="2005%20J.League%20Division%201">2005</a>).
In August 2006, Ogasawara moved to Italy and signed with <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> club <a href="A.C.R.%20Messina">Messina Peloro</a> on loan. However he could not play many matches.
In July 2007, Ogasawara returned to Antlers. He played many matches as defensive midfielder and Antlers won the champions in <a href="2007%20J.League%20Division%201">J1 League</a> for the first time in 6 years. Antlers also won the champions in <a href="2007%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">2007 Emperor's Cup</a>. Antlers won the champions in <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a> for 3 years in a row (<a href="2007%20J.League%20Division%201">2007</a>-<a href="2009%20J.League%20Division%201">2009</a>). In 2009, he was selected MVP award. From 2010 season, Antlers won the champions <a href="2010%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">2010 Emperor's Cup</a>, <a href="2011%20J.League%20Cup">2011</a>, <a href="2012%20J.League%20Cup">2012</a> and <a href="2015%20J.League%20Cup">2015 J.League Cup</a>. He was also MVP award in <a href="2015%20J.League%20Cup">2015 J.League Cup</a>. In 2016, Antlers won the champions in <a href="2016%20J1%20League">J1 League</a> and qualified for <a href="2016%20FIFA%20Club%20World%20Cup">2016 Club World Cup</a> as host country champions. At Club World Cup, he played 3 matches and won the 2nd place. Antlers also won the champions in <a href="2016%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">2016 Emperor's Cup</a>. From 2017, his opportunity to play decreased. In 2018, Antlers won the champions in <a href="2018%20AFC%20Champions%20League">AFC Champions League</a> first Asian title in the club history. He retired end of 2018 season.
National team career.
In April 1999, Ogasawara was selected <a href="Japan%20national%20under-20%20football%20team">Japan U-20 national team</a> for <a href="1999%20FIFA%20World%20Youth%20Championship">1999 World Youth Championship</a>. At this tournament, he played all 7 matches as offensive midfielder and Japan won the 2nd place.
On March 21, 2002, Ogasawara debuted for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> under manager <a href="Philippe%20Troussier">Philippe Troussier</a> against <a href="Ukraine%20national%20football%20team">Ukraine</a>. In June, he was selected Japan for <a href="2002%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2002 World Cup</a>. He played a match against <a href="Tunisia%20national%20football%20team">Tunisia</a>. Japan qualified to the knockout stage first time in Japan's history.
After 2002 World Cup, Ogasawara played many matches as starting member under manager <a href="Zico%20%28footballer%29">Zico</a>. He was selected Japan for <a href="2003%20FIFA%20Confederations%20Cup">2003 Confederations Cup</a> and <a href="2004%20AFC%20Asian%20Cup">2004 Asian Cup</a>. At 2004 Asian Cup, although he played only 2 matches, Japan won the champions. In 2005, he was selected Japan for <a href="2005%20FIFA%20Confederations%20Cup">2005 Confederations Cup</a> and played all 3 matches. In 2006, he was selected Japan for <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2006 World Cup</a>. Although he played 2 matches, Japan was eliminated in the group stages.
After 2006 World Cup, Ogasawara was not selected Japan for generational change. In February 2010, he was selected Japan by manager <a href="Takeshi%20Okada">Takeshi Okada</a>. He played for Japan for the first time in 4 years. He played 55 games and scored 7 goals for Japan until 2010.
